witnesses.name: Mathieu Thiery
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: Co-worker (he guarded calves, she guarded cows)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Dispute when he became herdsman for calves while she had charge of cows; later quarrel over shared plums
testimony.threat_quote: he would not have charge of the big ones for long

testimony.quarrel_subject: Had been keeping horse belonging to her husband with his, but returned it when he bought another

witnesses.name: Dieudonné
witnesses.occupation: paistre des vaches du moctrier de Boreche

testimony.quarrel_subject: His animals became mixed up with those she was guarding
testimony.threat_quote: Par dieu tu n'est guerre sage d'ainsy souhaiter mal a une personne dieu l'en veuille bien garder

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: later (cow was struck with a stick and became ill)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Expressed regret to her husband about large calves dying; husband said it was because of lack of water, witness objected

harms_alleged.target: two small calves and one large calf

testimony.quarrel_subject: Her husband had beaten two of his young bulls which strayed into their garden; he told them they should have it properly fenced; later fined her calves as 'bangard'
Asked if she wanted to send 2 large calves to herd; she said no because others did not do so

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: fell ill and died in 3 months

testimony.quarrel_subject: Had not paid her the 'vin' (customary payment/tip) after purchasing animals

witnesses.name: Henry Lorentz
witnesses.occupation: serviteur à Colas Lenfan de la Basse Lindre

timeline.subject: Jennon femme Lux Barquel
timeline.details: Substitut for PG de Lorraine at Dieuze states he has sufficient information about her reputation - threats and effects, much feared - and asks for depositions

timeline.subject: Jennon femme Lux Barquel
timeline.details: Initial interrogation; she provides biographical information and denies accusations

timeline.subject: Jennon femme Lux Barquel
timeline.details: Substitut for PG (at Nancy) asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Jennon femme Lux Barquel
timeline.details: Change de Nancy agrees to torture

timeline.subject: Jennon femme Lux Barquel
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture (strappado) for 2 hours; she would not confess. Critical marginal note that some jolts given by executioner were contrary to advice of Change

timeline.subject: Jennon femme Lux Barquel
timeline.details: Second interrogation under torture (racking); she still would not confess. Marginal note: 'ceste reiteration de question est contre le droit et la pratique'

timeline.subject: Jennon femme Lux Barquel
timeline.details: Substitut at Nancy proposes that she be renvoyée (released); Change de Nancy approves with firm note that in future the court at Dieuze should not repeat torture without new indices and approval from Change

timeline.subject: Jennon femme Lux Barquel
timeline.details: Note that she has been released

torture.restrictions: question ordinaire et extraordinaire approved, but executioner exceeded approved methods; repeated torture criticized as illegal

prior_accusations.context: Driven out of Chateaux Houé as witch (approximately 20 years before trial)
Her husband's parents claimed her parents had been chased out of La Motte as 'mauvaises gens'

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Lux Barquel
notable_quotes.french: he would not have charge of the big ones for long
notable_quotes.english: he would not have charge of the big ones for long
notable_quotes.context: Threat allegedly made to Mathieu Thiery during quarrel about herding duties

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon's husband
notable_quotes.context: Insult directed at young herdsman Dieudonné during quarrel

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Lux Barquel
notable_quotes.context: Insult directed at Dieudonné; she later claimed she was laughing when she said it

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Lux Barquel
notable_quotes.french: Par dieu tu n'est guerre sage d'ainsy souhaiter mal a une personne dieu l'en veuille bien garder
notable_quotes.english: By God you are not very wise to wish harm to a person like this, may God preserve them well from it
notable_quotes.context: Response to servant girl who wished that those who had given the cow sickness might have as much themselves

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Lux Barquel
notable_quotes.french: je me feroy prendre et diroy tout ce que je sauroy pour estre hors du monde
notable_quotes.english: I would let myself be taken and would say all that I knew in order to be out of the world
notable_quotes.context: Statement to Zenelle 2 years before trial, saying what she would do if she were actually a witch

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Lux Barquel
notable_quotes.french: de par sa foy qu'elle n'en scait rien
notable_quotes.english: by her faith that she knows nothing of it
notable_quotes.context: Response under torture when asked if she agreed there were witches in the world

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Lux Barquel
notable_quotes.french: prayed God that she were a witch, and that she would say so but could not damn her soul
notable_quotes.english: prayed God that she were a witch, and that she would say so but could not damn her soul
notable_quotes.context: Statement during second torture session, refusing to confess falsely

notable_quotes.speaker: Official (marginal note)
notable_quotes.french: ceste reiteration de question est contre le droit et la pratique
notable_quotes.english: this repetition of torture is against the law and practice
notable_quotes.context: Critical note in margin about the illegal second torture session

relationships.evidence_text: married present husband when they were both in service at Blanche Eglise, and had been married 18 years
married Mengeon from Pont-à-Mousson, who went into garrison at Marsal, then left with other soldiers 6 weeks after marriage - never saw him again, heard he had been killed
daughter of Pierron Beublait and his wife Jeannon of Chateaux Houé
daughter of Pierron Beublait and his wife Jeannon of Chateaux Houé
Zenelle femme du precedent (wife of the preceding witness)
2 years earlier he became herdsman for calves when she had charge of cows
paistre des vaches du moctrier de Boreche (herdsman for the cattle of Adloff Collin's farm at Boreche)
Henry Lorentz serviteur à Colas Lenfan de la Basse Lindre

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes related to her work as herdsman: conflicts over animal care, fines for animals straying, payment disputes (the 'vin' or customary payment). Her husband's parents opposed their marriage because she had no property while he did. Her parents were allegedly driven out of La Motte as 'mauvaises gens'. She worked as a servant from age 8-28, suggesting lower economic status. The 'bangard' fine (for allowing animals to stray) and disputes over shared plums indicate economic tensions.

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Quarrel during which she told him he would not have charge of the big ones for long

harms_catalog.harm_description: Horse fell ill and died within a day

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Had been keeping horse belonging to her husband with his, but finally returned it when he bought another

harms_catalog.harm_description: Cow became ill after being struck with a stick, still in danger
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Animals became mixed up; she called him 'fils de putain', her husband called him 'fils de sorcier'

harms_catalog.victim_name: Two small calves and one large calf
harms_catalog.harm_description: Calves died after witness objected to husband's explanation
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Witness expressed regret about dying calves to her husband, who said it was lack of water; witness objected that small ones should be dying too if that were the case
Her husband had beaten two of his young bulls which strayed into their garden, and he told him they ought to have it properly fenced off
Asked her if she wanted to send 2 large calves to herd; she said no because others did not do so

harms_catalog.harm_description: Fell ill and died in 3 months, saying he was sure she had made him ill
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Quarrel with witness (his wife, husband's niece) 6 years earlier
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: fell ill after quarrel, died in 3 months

harms_catalog.harm_description: Cow became ill (same incident as witness 4)
Second pig was found dead before he could kill it
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Had not paid her the 'vin' (customary payment)

harms_catalog.harm_description: Cow died same day as purchase
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Had not paid her the 'vin' for previous transaction

harms_catalog.harm_description: Ox became ill but recovered after her husband was sent to cure it
harms_catalog.method_alleged: not specified (but her husband was able to cure it, suggesting she caused it)

material_culture.context: Customary payment expected in transactions; refusing wine led to suspicion of bewitchment; also the 'vin' as payment for animal purchases
Shared plums that became subject of quarrel with witness 1
She claimed to have been looking at a sheet she had put on a hedge by the river; witness suspected she had been to sabbat instead
Used to strike cow on the back during quarrel with young herdsman
Claimed to know a 'recepte' in German to prevent wolves getting nearer than 9 paces from animals

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial; where accused lived and worked as herdsman
Birthplace of accused; place from which she was driven out as witch approximately 20 years before
Location of lower court where trial was conducted
Location of Change de Nancy (appeals court) that ultimately ordered her release
Place from which her parents were allegedly chased out as 'mauvaises gens'
Origin of her first husband Mengeon
Location of garrison where first husband served; home of witness Claude Cloppestein the butcher
Location where witnesses 4 and 10 worked as herdsmen
Path from river where witness saw her far from her house; she claimed to have been looking at a sheet on a hedge, but witness suspected sabbat attendance
Where she came to ask after the sick cow
Her garden that witness's bulls strayed into, leading to quarrel

historical_context.military_details: Her first husband Mengeon went into garrison at Marsal with other soldiers 6 weeks after marriage, then left and was reportedly killed
animal_predation: Wolves mentioned - she claimed to know a spell in German to keep wolves 9 paces away from animals
economic_hardship_indicators: Class tensions: husband's parents objected to marriage because she had no property
Parents driven out of communities as 'mauvaises gens'

officials_named.name: substitut for PG de Lorraine at Dieuze

legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: imprisoned during trial from June 30 to August 17, 1613

hearsay_chains.content: Had heard others blame her for deaths of horses
Hanzo Buisson had told her to leave because they were going to arrest her

emotional_state_notes: When asked at veillée why she allowed herself to be called witch, she tried to cry but shed no tears (witness 7)
During interrogation, explained everything in very reasonable manner
Maintained she could not damn her soul by confessing falsely even under extreme torture

third_parties.name: Jennon's daughter (unnamed)
third_parties.context: Told her mother that Mathieu Thiery was calling her a witch

third_parties.name: servant girl (unnamed)
third_parties.context: Wished those who had given the cow sickness might have it themselves; Jennon responded with warning about wishing harm

third_parties.name: Gros Claude
third_parties.context: Called accused witch the previous year without her taking legal action

third_parties.name: Hanzo Buisson
third_parties.context: Warned accused to leave because they were going to arrest her

third_parties.name: surgeon (unnamed)
third_parties.context: Treated her husband who had been 'taillé' (cut/operated on); said he went back to work too soon

third_parties.name: executioner (unnamed)
third_parties.context: Administered torture; criticized for giving jolts contrary to advice of Change de Nancy

third_parties.name: Lux Barquel's parents (unnamed)
third_parties.context: Hostile to marriage, claiming her parents had been chased out of La Motte as 'mauvaises gens' and that she had no property while their son did

third_parties.name: husband's nieces (unnamed, plural)
third_parties.context: Had called her witch according to witness 7

third_parties.name: Didier Lhuilier
third_parties.context: Died after quarrel between his wife and accused; said he was sure she had made him ill

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a particularly important case as it documents a woman who survived torture and was released. The trial record is detailed with 15 witnesses, comprehensive documentation of the torture sessions, and critical marginal notes indicating that the court at Dieuze exceeded its legal authority by repeating torture. The Change de Nancy intervened to stop illegal practices and ordered her release. The case reveals economic and social tensions around her work as a herdsman, class differences (her lack of property vs. husband's property), and prior expulsions from multiple communities. Her resistance under torture and refusal to confess falsely ('could not damn her soul') is notable. The critical legal annotations provide rare documentation of oversight mechanisms and limits on torture.
